Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Multifunctional Trilayer Membrane for a Stable, Scalable and Economical High Energy Capacity Li-S Battery with Long Cycle Life
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Technology Transfer (STTR) project will address concerns about the shortage of materials for Lithium-ion batteries as the number of electric vehicles increases. Lithium Sulfur (Li-S) batteries offer an opportunity because sulfur is more readily available, lower cost, and environmentally friendly. Unlike lead-acid batteries, Li-S batteries do not require use of sulfuric acid or other environmentally harmful chemicals. The global Li-S battery market will grow at an estimated annual rate of 70+% in the next 10 years, with a growth of nearly $700 M in 2018-2022. The proposed project will accelerate the development of advanced Li-S batteries.

This STTR Phase I project proposes to address important technical challenges like inferior reversibility and poor safety (stability) of the Li metal anode. Equivalent circuit network (ECN) models will be developed for simulating the performance of the new Li-S cells. Accurate and appropriate models are necessary for applications of Li-S batteries. Through experiments, systems modeling, and simulation, these objectives will be accomplished: 1) Gain better understanding of Li-S electrochemistry with a new cell using an advanced membrane, 2) Study effects of different operating parameters, such as the charge and discharge rate on the cell performance, 3) Conduct preliminary studies on the effect of temperature on the Li-S cell performance, 4) Demonstrate and report high energy and long cycle performance in Li-S pouch cell, 5) Li-S cells (coin and pouch cells) will be fabricated and their performance studied at different charge/discharge rates and temperature levels using precise testing equipment. The data will be used for ECN model development and simulation studies. The potential outcome(s) of the project include development of a new Li-S pouch cell incorporating an advanced composite membrane to enable the cell to have a capacity of over 400 Wh/kg and demonstrated cycle life of over 500 cycles.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit

This Small Business Technology Transfer Phase I project helped address important technical challenges facing the successful development and commercialization of lithium sulfur (Li-S) batteries. Through the support of this NSF STTR 1 project we were able to:

  • Successfully fabricated carbon coated sulphur (CCS) cathode for Li-S cell
  • Fabricated Li-S coin cells with CCS cathode, multifunctional trilayer separator and lithium metal anode
  • Successfully demonstrated that the multifunctional trilayer (modified) separator in fabricated Li-CCS cells acted as a barrier in preventing the shuttling of polysulfide by trapping them preferentially due to hydrophilic nature of the separator.
    • At 0.5C rate, modified separator exhibited high average capacity of 580 mAh g-1 compared to cell with pristine separator (370 mAh g-1)
    • For rate studies at room temperature, the capacities illustrated by pristine separator at 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.5C, 1C, 2C, 3C and 4C were 542, 483, 400, 358, 285, 248, and 217 mAh g-1, respectively. Capacity retention for 0.5C was ~ 93%. Compared to pristine, modified separator exhibited capacities of 925, 833, 644, 480, 326, 260, and 220 mAh g-1 at same C rates. Capacity retention for 0.5C rate was ~95%.
    • Rate studies at 20℃ (pristine separator) showed capacities of 377, 238, 178, 98, 84, and 67 mAh g-1 at 0.1C, 0.2C, 0.5C, 2C, 3C, and 4C, respectively. Modified separator again outperformed pristine separator with capacities of 565, 478, 360, 116, 93, and 67 mAh g-1 for same C rates.
    • At 0 ℃ for both modified and pristine separator, as shown in Fig. 1D. Modified separator showed stable cycling performance with average capacity of about 392 mAh g-1 as compared to 174 mAh g-1 of pristine separator, at 0.5C rate.
    • Used Matlab Simulink to replicate and simulate an equivalent circuit model for lithium polymer battery. Gained better insights on the strength and limitations of ECN models for battery cell development
    • Successfully developed a 1-D electrochemical model of our Li-CCS coin cell using COMSOL and validated the model results experimentally. Simulation results showed that the new advanced trilayer multifunctional separator is able to reduce polysulfide shuttling thereby resulting in better capacity retention in the Li-CCS cell. Simulation studies also showed that the precipitation of Li2S is higher at higher C rate resulting in more rapid capacity reduction in the cell.
    • One patent application, one journal publication and five conferences/presentations.

Broader/Commercial Impact

This NSF STTR 1 project has helped us significantly in moving our Li-S battery towards commercialization. Through the NSF support, we have

  • Conducted about 150 additional customer interviews through the 2020 NSF Bootcamp and 2020 Summer SBIR ICorps program that resulted in gaining a deeper understanding of the market and in developing strategic relationships with customers and collaborators
  • Established relationships with six (6) US drone manufacturers who are waiting to test and incorporate our new Li-S batteries in their drones
  • Established relationship with the nation?s leading police unmanned aircraft system (UAS) program and test center to test and adopt our advanced Li-S batteries in their fleet when developed
  • Established strategic relationships with a leading US lithium metal development company to access advanced technology and expertise to facilitate product development during our STTR Phase 2 as well as reduce the time to market
  • Secured an additional $76,500 to support our technology/product development and transition to STTR phase 2 through the Indiana Economic Development Corporation (through Elevate Venture); Indiana Radius business competition; and NSF SBIR ICorps

The broader impact of this project include:

  • Promoting the development and manufacture of advanced Li-S batteries in the US for drone and other applications:
    • Abundant and low-cost sulfur cathode unlike the foreign-supply dependent raw materials for lithium ion batteries
    • Higher energy density resulting in longer flight time for drones for commercial and military applications
    • Lower battery weight resulting in increasing payload
    • Enhanced safety
    • Compatibility with existing cell/battery manufacturing processes
    • Eco-friendly materials and processes that are safe for the environment and future generations
  • Manpower development for research and manufacturing of advanced battery systems in the US
    • One post-doc mentored
    • Two graduate students trained
    • One intern trained
    • Successful transition of a graduate student upon graduation into an employee at Valgotech LLC
